Award.AwardTitle: Analysis and Synthesis of Scattered Data on Surfaces via Radial and Related Basis Functions
Award.AbstractNarration: Ward<br/>DMS-0807033<br/><br/> The main object of this project is to develop new methods<br/>and tools for the analysis and synthesis of scattered data by<br/>means of radial and related basis functions. Very recently, the<br/>investigators Ward and Narcowich and a collaborator introduced a<br/>new tool for fitting a divergence-free vector field tangent to a<br/>2D orientable surface contained in 3D to samples of such a field<br/>taken at scattered sites on the surface. The method, which<br/>involves a kernel constructed from radial basis functions (RBFs),<br/>has applications to problems in geophysics -- for instance, the<br/>nonlinear flow of an incompressible fluid in a single hydrostatic<br/>atmospheric layer. Mathematically, incompressibility translates<br/>to the velocity having vanishing surface divergence. Fitting<br/>divergence-free tangent vector fields to data taken in these<br/>cases would help in modeling the incompressible velocity fields<br/>involved. In addition to handling scattered data, it has the<br/>advantage of avoiding special treatment for the poles. The<br/>investigators study the approximation properties of this tool,<br/>with a view towards estimates on its data-fitting errors as well<br/>how robust it is. For certain cases, numerical experiments<br/>suggest both a good fit of data and robustness. In addition,<br/>unstructured scattered data -- i.e., clumped, or clustered, or<br/>nonuniformly distributed data -- present problems for any method,<br/>including the traditional RBF-type algorithms based on translates<br/>of one conditionally positive definite function. These clustered<br/>data occur naturally in learning theory, neural nets, meshless<br/>methods, and other situations. To deal with clustered data, the<br/>investigators initiate the study of the construction of new<br/>bases, preconditioners, and in general a new RBF-type paradigm. <br/><br/> Problems that involve analyzing data taken from scattered<br/>sites -- that is, irregularly placed sites -- in space or on the<br/>surface of the earth arise frequently in diverse fields:<br/>computer-aided design graphics, data mining, medical imaging,<br/>learning networks, and geoscience, in addition to many other<br/>areas. Such problems present difficulties for traditional<br/>methods, which are based on collecting data at uniformly placed<br/>sites. For example, weather prediction is based on a<br/>mathematical model where the earth's surface is assumed to be a<br/>surface of a sphere. The investigators develop new methods and<br/>tools to help in analyzing such phenomena via so-called radial<br/>basis function methods. <br/>
